_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Alumina and Aluminum Production and Processing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Missouri Smelting Technology (MOST) has a comprehensive accidental release prevention and emergency response program.

Safe workplace practices are considered a condition of employment for all MOST employees.  By upholding the management principles of the Chlorine Institute, we exercise facility-wide responsible care.

MOST is a secondary aluminum smelter.  MOST utilizes chlorine to treat molten aluminum.  Construction of the facility was completed in February 1999.  The chlorine treatment system utilizes liquid chlorine stored in 1-ton containers.  A maximum of three 1-ton containers, or 6000 pounds is stored onsite at any time.  

Most's chlorine treatment system was developed utilizing numerous safety checks and release mitigation mechanisms.  The automatic shutoff valves will shut down the chlorine feed system in seconds in the case of a release.  Mechanical integrity inspections and preventive maintenance ensure the operational integrity of the process.

Employees involved with the chlorine process have a thorough understanding of pertinent operating procedures as well as the physical and chemical characteristics of chlorine.

There have been no accidents and no incidents in the past five years.

The Emergency Response Plan utilizes the Incident Command System, in which a plant incident commander provides mitigation direction to trained responders and communicates with local authorities as appropriate.  Annual training is provided for all chlorine process employees and quarterly evacuation drills are conducted.  The most recent emergency response training was provided on August 12, 2003 and the most recent evacuation drill was conducted on May 10, 2004.
